message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamics on higher-order networks: a review
Paper Abstract: Network science has evolved into an indispensable platform for studying complex systems. But recent research has identified limits of classical networks, where links connect pairs of nodes, to comprehensively describe group interactions. Higher-order networks, where a link can connect more than two nodes, have therefore emerged as a new frontier in network science. Since group interactions are common in social, biological and technological systems, higher-order networks have recently led to important new discoveries across many fields of research. Here, we review these works, focusing in particular on the novel aspects of the dynamics that emerges on higher-order networks. We cover a variety of dynamical processes that have thus far been studied, including different synchronization phenomena, contagion processes, the evolution of cooperation and consensus formation. We also outline open challenges and promising directions for future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Network science":

## Definition and Overview

Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks, considering distinct elements or actors represented by nodes (or vertices) and the connections between the elements or actors as links (or edges).(no content)The field draws on theories and methods including graph theory from mathematics, statistical mechanics from physics, data mining and information visualization from computer science, inferential modeling from statistics, and social structure from sociology.

## Historical Development

Interest in networks exploded around 2000, following new discoveries that offered novel mathematical framework to describe different network topologies. Albert-László Barabási and Reka Albert discovered the scale-free networks nature of many real networks, from the WWW to the cell.

## Applications

Network science has diverse applications across many fields:

- Social network analysis has been used to understand the diffusion of innovation, news and rumors, and to examine the spread of both diseases and health-related behaviors.
- It has been applied to the study of markets and to study recruitment into political movements and social organizations.
- In criminology, it is being used to identify influential actors in criminal gangs, offender movements, co-offending, predict criminal activities and make policies.

Luo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_C.J._Luo"},{"title":"Synchronous dynamic random-access memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronous_dynamic_random-access_memory"},{"title":"Coupled map lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupled_map_lattice"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of **synchronization dynamics**:

## General Overview

Synchronization is an emergent property that occurs in a broad range of dynamical systems, including neural signaling, the beating of the heart and the synchronization of fire-fly light waves.

## Types of Synchronization

In chaotic systems, there are several forms of synchronization:

1. **Complete Synchronization**: Systems are said to be completely synchronized when there is a set of initial conditions so that the systems eventually evolve identically in time.

2. **Phase Synchronization**: Phase synchronization occurs when the coupled chaotic oscillators keep their phase difference bounded while their amplitudes remain uncorrelated.

3. **Generalized Synchronization**: Generalized synchronization occurs when there is a functional relationship such that the dynamical state of one of the oscillators is completely determined by the state of the other.

## Synchronization Networks

A synchronization network is a network of coupled dynamical systems consisting of a network connecting oscillators, where oscillators are nodes that emit a signal with somewhat regular (possibly variable) frequency, and are also capable of receiving a signal.

The Kuramoto model was developed in the 1970s and 1980s to describe large systems of coupled oscillators.

## Applications

Synchronization dynamics have important applications in various fields, including physiology, neuroscience, and complex systems modeling.

Kaper - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_G._Kaper"},{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Animation/Cartoon Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Animation/Cartoon_Network"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of network mathematics:

## What is Network Mathematics?

In mathematics, computer science, and network science, network theory is a part of graph theory.(no content)It defines networks as graphs where the vertices or edges possess attributes.(no content)Network theory analyses these networks over the symmetric relations or asymmetric relations between their discrete components.

## Applications

Network theory has applications in many disciplines, including statistical physics, particle physics, computer science, electrical engineering, biology, archaeology, linguistics, economics, finance, operations research, climatology, ecology, public health, sociology, psychology, and neuroscience.(no content)Applications of network theory include logistical networks, the World Wide Web, Internet, gene regulatory networks, metabolic networks, social networks, epistemological networks, etc.

## Historical Context

Euler's solution of the Seven Bridges of Königsberg problem is considered to be the first true proof in the theory of networks.

## Key Problem Areas

Network problems that involve finding an optimal way of doing something are studied as combinatorial optimization. Examples include network flow, shortest path problem, transport problem, transshipment problem, location problem, matching problem, assignment problem, packing problem, routing problem, critical path analysis, and program evaluation and review technique.

Network mathematics provides a powerful framework for understanding complex systems across numerous scientific and practical domains.

Kaper - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_G._Kaper"},{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Animation/Cartoon Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Animation/Cartoon_Network"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of network mathematics:

## What is Network Mathematics?

In mathematics, computer science, and network science, network theory is a part of graph theory.(no content)It defines networks as graphs where the vertices or edges possess attributes.(no content)Network theory analyses these networks over the symmetric relations or asymmetric relations between their discrete components.

## Applications

Network theory has applications in many disciplines, including statistical physics, particle physics, computer science, electrical engineering, biology, archaeology, linguistics, economics, finance, operations research, climatology, ecology, public health, sociology, psychology, and neuroscience.(no content)Applications of network theory include logistical networks, the World Wide Web, Internet, gene regulatory networks, metabolic networks, social networks, epistemological networks, etc.

## Historical Context

Euler's solution of the Seven Bridges of Königsberg problem is considered to be the first true proof in the theory of networks.

## Key Problem Areas

Network problems that involve finding an optimal way of doing something are studied as combinatorial optimization. Examples include network flow, shortest path problem, transport problem, transshipment problem, location problem, matching problem, assignment problem, packing problem, routing problem, critical path analysis, and program evaluation and review technique.

Network mathematics provides a powerful framework for understanding complex systems across numerous scientific and practical domains.

Based on the search results, here's information about higher-order networks and hypergraphs:

## Basic Definition

A hypergraph is a generalization of a graph in which an edge can join any number of vertices. In contrast, in an ordinary graph, an edge connects exactly two vertices.(no content)A hypergraph is a generalization of a graph in which each edge (called a hyperedge in this context) may have more than two endpoints.

## Key Characteristics

A hypergraph H is a pair (V, E), where V is a set of vertices and E is a set of subsets of V called hyperedges. Each hyperedge may contain one or more vertices.

A special case of hypergraphs is a hypergraph whose edges all have size k, called k-uniform. A 2-uniform hypergraph is a graph.

## Applications

Undirected hypergraphs are useful in modelling such things as satisfiability problems, databases, machine learning, and Steiner tree problems. They have been extensively used in machine learning tasks as the data model and classifier regularization. The applications include recommender system (communities as hyperedges), image retrieval (correlations as hyperedges), and bioinformatics (biochemical interactions as hyperedges).

Additionally, researchers have begun to revisit and re-evaluate most existing graph models in the heterophily scenario across various kinds of graphs, including hypergraphs.

Web search results for query: "Contagion epidemic spreading"

Links: [{"title":"Epidemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic"},{"title":"Contagion (2011 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contagion_(2011_film)"},{"title":"Contagious disease - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contagious_disease"},{"title":"Crimson Contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimson_Contagion"},{"title":"Complex contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_contagion"},{"title":"Compartmental models (epidemiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compartmental_models_in_epidemiology"},{"title":"Disease outbreak - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease_outbreak"},{"title":"Superspreading event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superspreading_event"},{"title":"Social contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contagion"},{"title":"Pandemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pandemic"}]

I've completed the web search for "Contagion epidemic spreading". Here are the key findings:

## What is an Epidemic?

An epidemic is the rapid spread of disease to a large number of hosts in a given population within a short period of time.(no content)The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines epidemic broadly as "an increase, often sudden, in the number of cases of a disease above what is normally expected in that population in that area."

## Contagious Diseases

A contagious disease is an infectious disease that can be spread rapidly in several ways, including direct contact, indirect contact, and droplet contact.(no content)These diseases are caused by organisms such as parasites, bacteria, fungi, and viruses.

## How Epidemics Spread

Epidemics of infectious disease are generally caused by several factors including a change in the ecology of the host population, a genetic change in the pathogen reservoir or the introduction of an emerging pathogen to a host population.(no content)In a propagated outbreak, the disease spreads person-to-person.

## Pandemic vs. Epidemic

A pandemic is an epidemic of an infectious disease that has a sudden increase in cases and spreads across a large region, for instance multiple continents or worldwide, affecting a substantial portion of the human population.

The search results also included information about the 2011 film "Contagion" and various models for understanding disease transmission patterns.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Consensus formation"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reducing consensus to an algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reducing_consensus_to_an_algorithm"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Consensus"},{"title":"Scientific consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_consensus"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Method for consensus building - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Method_for_consensus_building"},{"title":"Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus"},{"title":"Consensus theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory"},{"title":"Consensus theory of truth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory_of_truth"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of consensus formation:

## General Definition

Consensus usually refers to general agreement among a group of people or community.

## Consensus Decision-Making

Consensus decision-making is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve a broad acceptance.(no content)Consensus is reached when everyone in the group assents to a decision (or almost everyone) even if some do not fully agree to or support all aspects of it.(no content)It differs from simple unanimity, which requires all participants to support a decision.

## Historical Development

Consensus decision-making, as a self-described practice, originates from several nonviolent, direct action groups that were active in the Civil rights, Peace and Women's movements in the USA during counterculture of the 1960s.

## Technical Applications

In computing and multi-agent systems, consensus dynamics studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

## Scientific Consensus

Scientific consensus is the majority judgment and position by active, qualified experts in a specific scientific discipline to establish a conclusion or fact.(no content)Scientific consensus results from the self-correcting scientific process of peer review, replication of the event through the scientific method, scholarly debate, meta-analysis, and publication of high-quality review articles.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reducing consensus to an algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reducing_consensus_to_an_algorithm"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Consensus"},{"title":"Scientific consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_consensus"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Method for consensus building - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Method_for_consensus_building"},{"title":"Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus"},{"title":"Consensus theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory"},{"title":"Consensus theory of truth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory_of_truth"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of consensus formation:

## General Definition

Consensus usually refers to general agreement among a group of people or community.

## Consensus Decision-Making

Consensus decision-making is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve a broad acceptance.(no content)Consensus is reached when everyone in the group assents to a decision (or almost everyone) even if some do not fully agree to or support all aspects of it.(no content)It differs from simple unanimity, which requires all participants to support a decision.

## Historical Development

Consensus decision-making, as a self-described practice, originates from several nonviolent, direct action groups that were active in the Civil rights, Peace and Women's movements in the USA during counterculture of the 1960s.

## Technical Applications

In computing and multi-agent systems, consensus dynamics studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

## Scientific Consensus

Scientific consensus is the majority judgment and position by active, qualified experts in a specific scientific discipline to establish a conclusion or fact.(no content)Scientific consensus results from the self-correcting scientific process of peer review, replication of the event through the scientific method, scholarly debate, meta-analysis, and publication of high-quality review articles.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Cooperation evolution game theory"

Links: [{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"The Complexity of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Complexity_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Reciprocity (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(evolution)"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism_in_humans"},{"title":"Tit for tat - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tit_for_tat"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)"}]

Here are the search results for "Cooperation evolution game theory":

## Overview

Evolutionary game theory can be applied to the prisoner's dilemma game to test the payoffs of cooperating or defecting from cooperation, helping to explain how cooperation evolves in nature despite seemingly self-interested behavior.

## Key Concepts

**The Prisoner's Dilemma**: The prisoner's dilemma codifies the problem of cooperation and has been the subject of much research, both theoretical and experimental. A difficulty recognized by Darwin himself was the problem of altruism - if the basis for selection is at an individual level, altruism makes no sense at all.

**Reciprocity**: Reciprocity in evolutionary biology refers to mechanisms whereby the evolution of cooperative or altruistic behaviour may be favoured by the probability of future mutual interactions. Direct reciprocity was proposed by Robert Trivers as a mechanism for the evolution of cooperation - if there are repeated encounters between the same two players in an evolutionary game, a strategy of mutual cooperation may be favoured.

## The Tit-for-Tat Strategy

A strategy called "tit for tat" (TFT) that cooperates on the first move, and subsequently echoes what the other player did on the previous move, emerged as the winner in game theory tournaments. In tournaments, the best-performing strategies were nice: that is, they were never the first to defect.

## Key Success Factors

Success in an evolutionary "game" correlated with these characteristics: Be nice - cooperate and never be the first to defect; Be provocable - return defection for defection and cooperation for cooperation; Don't be envious - focus on maximizing your own 'score'.

Web search results for query: "Complex systems"

Links: [{"title":"Complex system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_system"},{"title":"Complex adaptive system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_adaptive_system"},{"title":"Category:Complex systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Complex_systems_theory"},{"title":"Large-scale Complex IT Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large-scale_Complex_IT_Systems"},{"title":"Advances in Complex Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advances_in_Complex_Systems"},{"title":"New England Complex Systems Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England_Complex_Systems_Institute"},{"title":"Complex and Adaptive Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_and_Adaptive_Systems_Laboratory"},{"title":"Complex systems biology","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_systems_biology"},{"title":"Complex Systems (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_Systems_(journal)"},{"title":"Complex dynamic systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_dynamic_systems_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "Complex systems":

## Overview

A complex system is a system composed of many components that interact with one another.(no content)The term complex systems often refers to the study of complex systems, which is an approach to science that investigates how relationships between a system's parts give rise to its collective behaviors and how the system interacts and forms relationships with its environment.

## Key Characteristics

Systems that are "complex" have distinct properties that arise from these relationships, such as nonlinearity, emergence, spontaneous order, adaptation, and feedback loops, among others.(no content)The behavior of a complex system is intrinsically difficult to model due to the dependencies, competitions, relationships, and other types of interactions between their parts or between a given system and its environment.

## Examples

Examples of complex systems are Earth's global climate, organisms, the human brain, infrastructure such as power grid, transportation or communication systems, complex software and electronic systems, social and economic organizations (like cities), an ecosystem, a living cell, and, ultimately, for some authors, the entire universe.

## Interdisciplinary Nature

Complex systems is therefore often used as a broad term encompassing a research approach to problems in many diverse disciplines, including statistical physics, information theory, nonlinear dynamics, anthropology, computer science, meteorology, sociology, economics, psychology, and biology.

## Complex Adaptive Systems

Complex adaptive systems are special cases of complex systems that are adaptive in that they have the capacity to change and learn from experience.(no content)Examples of complex adaptive systems include the international trade markets, social insect and ant colonies, the biosphere and the ecosystem, the brain and the immune system, the cell and the developing embryo, cities, manufacturing businesses and any human social group-based endeavor in a cultural and social system such as political parties or communities.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
todos.activeForm: Searching for Wikipedia articles for each entity

todos.content: Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all entity information

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

**Paper Classification:** Survey (literature review)

4. **Synchronization** - Key dynamical process on networks
5. **Epidemic** - Model for studying contagion/spreading dynamics

7. **Consensus dynamics** - Process of reaching agreement through networks
